title: What is the difference between R&B and Jazz? - Quora

response.answer_text: both genres obviously share a common ancestry with an older form, the blues. in their time lines, r’n’b emerged roughly two to three generations after jazz did. it was largely a creation of a northern migration, mostly within the u.s., from the original cradle of blues and jazz, which went on between the two world wars, the industrial boom of the second world war, and the early cold war period. jazz musicians were among the earliest migrants, getting their start before the great war, using the same routes, the river, highways, and railroad, to many of the very same places like Chicago. the 1950s saw r’n’b emerging as a popular music, bebop transforming to post-bebop post-modern jazz, and the first generation of what the u.s. calls ‘baby boomers’ coming of age. it’s why both jazz and r’n’b are associated with the reform movements for civil rights and the Viet Nam war. it’s possible something similar to the r’n’b we know could have evolved without the big dose of urban influences, which included jazz, but musicians being as fluid and mobile in their choice of workplace as they are, we’ll never know. we’re reminded of their consanguinity every time there’s a jazz arrangement of an r’n’b tune, or of course one adapted in the other direction. hip hop uses samples of classic jazz recordings, for that matter. the distinctive ‘motown sound’ from Detroit came from jazz musicians, and the city is associated with many great players through the years. if you listen closely to arrangements on the recordings of r’n’b classics, you can often distinguish the Det made recordings from those of Memphis or Muscle Shoals or Philadelphia. as for what differentiates the two genres when we experience them, here’s one reductionist model, and better qualified musicologists might have something more sophisticated. for r’n’b, the rhythmic foundation provided by two specific instruments, the bass and the drums, has narrower parameters for providing the pulse, and its syncopation is more structured. the structure is very close to Afro-american church music, usually cited as a principal source for r’n’b, also closely associated with the civil rights movement of the early 60s. improvisation is a secondary priority in r’n’b or church music. jazz simply permits more liberties, far more with some practitioners.
